robots_txt.eli5: It's like a sign on your front door telling robots which rooms they can or can’t go into.
robots_txt.boss: Robots.txt is a file that tells search engines which parts of your website to crawl or ignore.
robots_txt.sysadmin: A plain text file placed at the root of a domain to guide search engine bots on which URLs should not be crawled using user-agent directives.
robots_txt.use_case: Used to block bots from crawling private admin URLs or staging environments.

sitemap_xml.eli5: It's like a treasure map that helps search engines find all your web pages.
sitemap_xml.boss: Sitemap.xml is a structured file that helps search engines discover and index your site's pages.
sitemap_xml.sysadmin: An XML file listing URLs on a website, with optional metadata such as lastmod, changefreq, and priority for SEO crawling.
sitemap_xml.use_case: Used to submit a complete list of website URLs to Google Search Console for indexing.

google_search_console.eli5: It’s like a dashboard that tells you how your website is doing in Google search.
google_search_console.boss: Google Search Console is a free tool from Google to monitor, maintain, and troubleshoot your website’s presence in search results.
google_search_console.sysadmin: A suite of web tools by Google to monitor site indexing, fix crawl issues, view search queries, and submit sitemaps.
google_search_console.use_case: Used to track keyword performance and submit new pages for indexing.

bing_webmaster_tools.eli5: It’s like the Bing version of Google Search Console to track how your site shows up.
bing_webmaster_tools.boss: Bing Webmaster Tools lets site owners see how their site performs in Bing search and fix issues.
bing_webmaster_tools.sysadmin: A set of diagnostics, SEO, and crawl tools for managing site indexing and visibility on Bing's search engine.
bing_webmaster_tools.use_case: Used to view crawl errors and keyword insights for Bing search traffic.

accessibility_a11y.eli5: Making websites easy for everyone to use—even people with vision or hearing problems.
accessibility_a11y.boss: Accessibility ensures websites are usable by people with disabilities, improving reach and compliance.
accessibility_a11y.sysadmin: Web accessibility (a11y) involves ARIA roles, semantic HTML, contrast ratios, keyboard navigation, and screen reader support.
accessibility_a11y.use_case: Used to meet WCAG standards and improve usability for all users.

screen_reader.eli5: It’s like a narrator that reads the website out loud to people who can’t see it.
screen_reader.boss: Screen readers convert on-screen content into speech or Braille, enabling access for visually impaired users.
screen_reader.sysadmin: Assistive software that interprets screen content and conveys it through synthetic speech or Braille output, relying on semantic HTML and ARIA roles.
screen_reader.use_case: Used by visually impaired users to navigate and interact with websites.

contrast_ratio.eli5: It’s like making sure there’s enough difference between colors so you can read the words easily.
contrast_ratio.boss: Contrast ratio measures how well text stands out from the background, affecting readability and accessibility.
contrast_ratio.sysadmin: The luminance contrast between foreground (text) and background colors, with WCAG requiring a minimum ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text.
contrast_ratio.use_case: Used to verify that a site’s color scheme is readable by people with visual impairments.

focus_ring.eli5: It’s like a glowing outline that shows where you are on a website when using your keyboard.
focus_ring.boss: Focus rings visually indicate which element on a web page is currently selected via keyboard navigation.
focus_ring.sysadmin: Browser-drawn outlines (default or custom CSS) that show focus state of interactive elements like links or buttons, crucial for keyboard accessibility.
focus_ring.use_case: Used to help keyboard users track their navigation without a mouse.
